description.summary: Scottish water spirit that appears as a horse near rivers and lochs. Lures humans (especially children) to ride, then drowns them. Can shapeshift into human form with telltale signs of cold, wet skin and water plants in hair.
description.full: The kelpie is a malevolent water spirit from Scottish folklore that typically manifests as a beautiful black horse near rivers and lochs. The creature lures unsuspecting humans, particularly children, to mount it, at which point the rider becomes stuck to the kelpie's adhesive skin and is dragged underwater to drown and be devoured. Kelpies can also appear in human form, usually as handsome young men or beautiful women, but always betray their nature through cold, wet skin and water weeds entangled in their hair. In Scottish folklore, kelpies served as cautionary tales warning children about the dangers of water. Capture is possible by bridling the kelpie, which removes its power and makes it an obedient servant. Weaknesses include silver, rowan wood, and speaking its true name. The kelpie represents the deceptive beauty and deadly danger of water, particularly Scotland's deep lochs and fast-flowing rivers.

range.description: Throughout Scotland, particularly Highlands and islands. Found wherever there are rivers, lochs, and streams. Similar creatures in Wales, Isle of Man, and Ireland.

first_recorded.source: Scottish oral traditions, written records from 16th century

temporal.seasonal_patterns: Tales occur year-round but often set in summer when children played near water

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient Scottish water spirit folklore, serving as cautionary tales about water dangers. Reflects the deadly nature of Scotland's deep lochs and swift rivers.
origins.earliest_accounts: Oral traditions predate written records; documented since at least the 16th century in Scottish texts.
origins.folklore_connections: Part of broader Celtic water spirit tradition. Related to each-uisge, nuckelavee, and similar to Welsh ceffyl dŵr and Manx cabyll-ushtey. Parallels with Germanic nixie and Scandinavian nøkk.

timeline.significance: Kelpie tales serve as water safety warnings in Scottish communities
Kelpie folklore begins appearing in written Scottish texts
Victorian interest in Scottish folklore brings kelpie tales to wider audience
Massive kelpie head sculptures become Scottish landmarks
timeline.source: Public art installation by Andy Scott

history.modern_era: Kelpie folklore remains strong in Scottish culture. The massive Kelpies sculptures near Falkirk (completed 2013) demonstrate continued cultural significance. Kelpies appear frequently in Scottish literature, fantasy fiction, and tourism.

traditions: Cautionary tales about beautiful but dangerous things
Tales of kelpie servants doing impossible labor
stories: The Black Horse of Loch Rannoch
Stories of bridled kelpies building bridges and churches overnight
folklore.beliefs: Kelpies served practical purpose as cautionary tales warning children away from dangerous water. Some believed placing iron or rowan near water provided protection.

indigenous.significance: Central to Scottish water spirit folklore. Reflects real dangers of Scottish waters - deep lochs, strong currents, cold temperatures. Tales taught respect for and wariness of water.
indigenous.sensitivity_note: Kelpie folklore is traditional Scottish cultural heritage, part of living folklore traditions.
indigenous.respect_guidelines: Recognize kelpie tales as meaningful cultural heritage with practical origins in water safety education.
